details.title: Parametric Programming Approach for a Two-Unit Repairable System With Imperfect Coverage, Reboot and Fuzzy Parameters

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Appl. Stat., Nat. Taichung Inst. of Technol., Taichung

p: Jau-Chuan Ke is a Professor of Applied Statistics at National Taichung Institute of Technology, Taiwan. He received his M.S. in Applied Mathematics at National Cheng-Kung University, Taiwan; and his Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics at National Chung-Hsing University, Taiwan. His research interests include reliability, statistics, and queueing theory.

authors.name: Jau-Chuan Ke

p: Hsin-I. Huang is an Associate Professor of Computer Science and Information Engineering at National Taichung Institute of Technology, Taiwan. She received her M.S. in Education from Boston University, USA. Her research interests include fuzzy theory, mathematics, and statistics.

Chuen-Horng Lin is an Associate Professor of Information Management at National Taichung Institute of Technology, Taiwan. He received his M.S. and Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics at National Chung-Hsing University, Taiwan. His research interests include reliability, fuzzy theory, image processing, and network theory.

details.abstract: This paper proposes a procedure for constructing the membership functions of the system characteristics of a two-unit repairable system in which the coverage factor for an operating unit failure is possibly considered. Times to failure, and times to repair of the operating units are assumed to follow fuzzified exponential distributions. In addition, the recovery times, and reboot times of the failed units also follow fuzzified exponential distributions. The alpha-cut approach is used to extract the fuzzy repairable system from a family of conventional crisp intervals for the desired system characteristics, determined with a set of parametric nonlinear programs using their membership functions. Two numerical examples illustrate the practicality of the proposed approach. Because the system characteristics are governed by the membership functions, more information is provided for use by designers and practitioners. The successful extension of the parameter spaces to fuzzy environments permits the repairable system to have wider practical applications.

references.title:
Bibliography for reliability and availability of stochastic
systems

context.text: Redundant repairable systems have been studied extensively in the past, and detailed bibliographies are found in Osaki & Nakagawa [1], and Srinivasan & Subramanian [2].

links.abstract: A brief review of stochastic models on system-reliability lists selected references on system reliability models using stochastic processes such as Markov chains, Markov processes, renewal processes, and semi-Markov (Markov renewal) processes.

references.text: S. Osaki, T. Nakagawa, "Bibliography for reliability and availability of stochastic systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-25, pp. 284-287, 1976.

references.title: Probabilistic analysis of redundant systems

context.text: Redundant repairable systems have been studied extensively in the past, and detailed bibliographies are found in Osaki & Nakagawa [1], and Srinivasan & Subramanian [2].

references.title:
Profit analysis of a two-unit redundant
system with provision for test and correlated failures and repairs

context.text: A number of authors have investigated the two-unit redundant systems under different assumptions (see de Goel & Shrivastava [3], Almeida & Campello de Souza [4], Gururajan & Srinivasan [5], Rajamanickam & Chandrasekar [6], Billinton & Pan [7], Yadavalli et al. [8], and Seo et al. [9]).

references.text: L. R. Goel, P. Shrivastava, "Profit analysis of a two-unit redundant system with provision for test and correlated failures and repairs", Microelectronics and Reliability, vol. 31, pp. 827-833, 1991.

references.title:
Decision theory in maintenance
strategy for a 2-unit redundant standby system

context.text: A number of authors have investigated the two-unit redundant systems under different assumptions (see de Goel & Shrivastava [3], Almeida & Campello de Souza [4], Gururajan & Srinivasan [5], Rajamanickam & Chandrasekar [6], Billinton & Pan [7], Yadavalli et al. [8], and Seo et al. [9]).

However, while these results can be useful in analysis, and assist the decision process, there are very few studies that establish a decision model which directly determines an optimum maintenance strategy. de Almeida & Campello de Souza [4] constructed a decision model using a Bayesian approach & selected utility functions.

links.abstract: Obtaining a good maintenance strategy for a standby system is discussed. The problem is analyzed via decision theory to determine the waiting time to call the repair facility (for a two-unit standby system) when the first piece of equipment fails. Previous research into this kind of system is briefly described, and a need for constructing a decision model is explained. The uncertainty of the parameters is accounted for in a Bayes approach in order to consider expert prior knowledge. The failure ...

references.text: A. T. de Almeida, F. M. Campello de Souza, "Decision theory in maintenance strategy for a 2-unit redundant standby system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 42, no. 3, pp. 401-407, 1993.

references.title: Probability and Statistics with Reliability, Queueing and Computer Science Applications

context.text: Faults in the above cases are said to be not covered, and the probability that a given fault belongs to this class is denoted by \$1-c\$, where \$c\$ denotes the probability of occurrences of covered faults, and is known as the coverage factor or coverage parameter (see Trivedi [10]).
Recently, Trivedi [10] proposed a reliability model with three phases of failure handling: failure detection, location, and recovery for continued service.

references.text: K. S. Trivedi, Probability and Statistics with Reliability Queueing and Computer Science Applications, 2002, John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

references.title: Fuzzy theory in reliability analysis

context.text: The concept of fuzzy reliability has been introduced and developed by several authors (Onisawa [14], and Cai et al. [15]–[18]).

references.text: T. Onisawa, "Fuzzy theory in reliability analysis", Fuzzy Sets and Systems, vol. 29, pp. 250-251, 1989.

references.title:
Fuzzy variables as a basis for a theory
of fuzzy reliability in the possibility context

context.text: [15]–[18], various forms of fuzzy reliability theory can be considered by making new assumptions, such as the possibility assumption (possibility distribution), or the fuzzy-state assumption, in place of the probability assumption (probability distribution), or the binary-state assumption respectively.
[15], the fuzzy system reliability was established based on the binary-state assumption, and possibility assumption.

references.text: K. Y. Cai, C. Y. Wen, M. L. Zhang, "Fuzzy variables as a basis for a theory of fuzzy reliability in the possibility context", Fuzzy Sets and Systems, vol. 42, pp. 145-172, 1991.

references.title:
Posbist reliability behavior of typical
system with two types of failures

context.text: The concept of fuzzy reliability has been introduced and developed by several authors (Onisawa [14], and Cai et al. [15]–[16][18]).

According to the studies by Cai et al. [15]–[16][18], various forms of fuzzy reliability theory can be considered by making new assumptions, such as the possibility assumption (possibility distribution), or the fuzzy-state assumption, in place of the probability assumption (probability distribution), or the binary-state assumption respectively.
[16], the fuzzy system reliability was established based on the three-state assumption, and possibility assumption.

references.text: K. Y. Cai, C. Y. Wen, M. L. Zhang, "Posbist reliability behavior of typical system with two types of failures", Fuzzy Sets and Systems, vol. 43, pp. 17-32, 1991.

According to the studies by Cai et al. [15]–[17][18], various forms of fuzzy reliability theory can be considered by making new assumptions, such as the possibility assumption (possibility distribution), or the fuzzy-state assumption, in place of the probability assumption (probability distribution), or the binary-state assumption respectively.
[17], the reliability of the fuzzy system was developed based on the fuzzy-state assumption, and the probability assumption.

references.text: K. Y. Cai, C. Y. Wen, M. L. Zhang, "Fuzzy states as a basis for a theory of fuzzy reliability", Microelectronics and Reliability, vol. 33, pp. 2253-2263, 1993.

references.title: A numerical algorithm of fuzzy reliability

context.text: Recently, Jiang & Chen [22] developed a computational model of fuzzy reliability focusing on solving the engineering problems with random general stress, and fuzzy general strength.

references.text: Q. Jiang, C.-H. Chen, "A numerical algorithm of fuzzy reliability", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 80, pp. 299-307, 2003.

references.title: Decision Making under Uncertainly: Models and Choices

context.text: Because the parameter patterns of time-to-failure and time-to-repair are possibilistic (the strength of the parameter patterns) rather than deterministic, the reliability (or availability) problem becomes one of decision making in the context of risk (see Holloway [23]).

To broaden applications of reliability & availability analyses in engineering (see Cleland & Kocaoglu [24]), general science, and management (Holloway [23]), this article extends the parameter distributions to fuzzy environments (see Zadeh [25]).

references.text: C. A. Holloway, Decision Making under Uncertainly: Models and Choices, 1979, Prentice-Hall.

references.title: Engineering Management

context.text: To broaden applications of reliability & availability analyses in engineering (see Cleland & Kocaoglu [24]), general science, and management (Holloway [23]), this article extends the parameter distributions to fuzzy environments (see Zadeh [25]).

links.abstract: Projects are to be found throughout the history of mankind. These projects have created change or have been carded out as responses to change. Project Management has had a major impact on the theory and practice of management.

references.text: D. I. Cleland, D. F. Kocaoglu, Engineering Management, 1981, McGraw-Hill.

references.title: Fuzzy sets as a basis for a theory of possibility

context.text: To broaden applications of reliability & availability analyses in engineering (see Cleland & Kocaoglu [24]), general science, and management (Holloway [23]), this article extends the parameter distributions to fuzzy environments (see Zadeh [25]).

Following Zadeh's extension principle (see Zadeh [25], and Prade [26]), the membership function of the system characteristic \$f(\widetilde{\lambda},\widetilde{\theta},\widetilde{\mu},\widetilde{\beta})\$ is defined as Following (2) & (8), the membership functions for \$MTTF \eta_{\widetilde{T}}(z)\$, and availability \$\eta_{\widetilde{A}}(z)\$ are and with \$\Omega_{1}=\{x\in X,v\in V,y\in Y\vert x>0,v>0,y>0\}\$, and \$\Omega_{2}=\{x\in X,v\in V,y\in Y,w\in W\vert x>0,v>0,\,y>0,w>0\}\$.

references.text: L. A. Zadeh, "Fuzzy sets as a basis for a theory of possibility", Fuzzy Sets and Systems, vol. 1, pp. 3-28, 1978.

references.title: An Outline of Fuzzy or Possibilistic Models for Queueing Systems, Fuzzy Sets

context.text: Following Zadeh's extension principle (see Zadeh [25], and Prade [26]), the membership function of the system characteristic \$f(\widetilde{\lambda},\widetilde{\theta},\widetilde{\mu},\widetilde{\beta})\$ is defined as Following (2) & (8), the membership functions for \$MTTF \eta_{\widetilde{T}}(z)\$, and availability \$\eta_{\widetilde{A}}(z)\$ are and with \$\Omega_{1}=\{x\in X,v\in V,y\in Y\vert x>0,v>0,y>0\}\$, and \$\Omega_{2}=\{x\in X,v\in V,y\in Y,w\in W\vert x>0,v>0,\,y>0,w>0\}\$.

references.text: H. M. Prade, An Outline of Fuzzy or Possibilistic Models for Queueing Systems Fuzzy Sets, 1980, Plenum Press.

references.title: Introduction to the Theory of Fuzzy Subsets

context.text: The \$\alpha\$-cuts form a nested structure with respect to \$\alpha\$ (see Kaufmann [27], and Zimmermann [28]); i.e., given that \$0<\alpha_{2}<\alpha_{1}\leq 1,\,[x_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},x_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [x_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},x_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}],\,[v_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},v_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [v_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},v_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}]\$, and \$[y_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},y_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [y_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},y_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}]\$ are gained.

Again, by applying the results of Kaufmann [27], Zimmermann [28], and convexity properties to \$\widetilde{T},\,(T)_{\alpha_{1}}^{L}\geq (T)_{\alpha_{2}}^{L}\$ and \$(T)_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}\leq (T)_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}\$ are obtained, where \$0<\alpha_{2}<\alpha_{1}\leq 1\$.

references.text: A. Kaufmann, Introduction to the Theory of Fuzzy Subsets, vol. 1, 1975, Academic Press.

references.title: Fuzzy Set Theory and Its Applications

context.text: The \$\alpha\$-cuts form a nested structure with respect to \$\alpha\$ (see Kaufmann [27], and Zimmermann [28]); i.e., given that \$0<\alpha_{2}<\alpha_{1}\leq 1,\,[x_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},x_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [x_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},x_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}],\,[v_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},v_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [v_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},v_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}]\$, and \$[y_{\alpha_{1}}^{L},y_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}]\subseteq [y_{\alpha_{2}}^{L},y_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}]\$ are gained.

Again, by applying the results of Kaufmann [27], Zimmermann [28], and convexity properties to \$\widetilde{T},\,(T)_{\alpha_{1}}^{L}\geq (T)_{\alpha_{2}}^{L}\$ and \$(T)_{\alpha_{1}}^{U}\leq (T)_{\alpha_{2}}^{U}\$ are obtained, where \$0<\alpha_{2}<\alpha_{1}\leq 1\$.

references.text: H. J. Zimmermann, Fuzzy Set Theory and Its Applications, 2001, Kluwer Academic.

references.title: Postoptimal Analysis, Parametric Programming, and Related Topics

references.text: T. Gal, Postoptimal Analysis Parametric Programming and Related Topics, 1979, McGraw-Hill.

references.title:
A procedure for ordering fuzzy subsets of
the unit interval

context.text: To address this demand, the fuzzy values of system characteristics are defuzzified using Yager's ranking index method [30].

on area compensation

context.text: Note that this method is a robust ranking technique that possesses the properties of compensation, linearity, and additivity (see Fortemps & Roubens [31]).
